titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV. Saturday.

Charles went in to Boston and returned to dine. He brought out the remainder of the books I had purchased at the Sale of my brother’s Library— Mr P. C. Brooks called here before dinner; going to meet part of his family at the Railway house— I visited my garden and Nursery, and planted a row of wild Cherries; and a row of Woodhouse Apple seeds in the Garden— Wrote to R Rush— At 4. in the afternoon I attended the funeral of Dr Phipps, which was performed with impressive solemnity; we followed (Charles and I) with the procession of Carriages from the dwelling house of the decease’d to the Meeting House— The Coffin was there taken up the central aisle and placed there during the performance of Religious worship— Mr Peter Whitney, read Selections from the New Testament and made an appropriate prayer His Son George Whitney preached a short and well adapted Sermon, from Romans 14.7.— “And no Man dieth to himself.” A hymn and a dirge were sung by the Choir after which the coffin was taken over to the cemetery and deposited in the family tomb— The House was well filled, and there was great solemnity in the performance— Mr Dawes and Mr Cranch were here in the Evening— Dr. Spooner was here this afternoon
2. V:45. Sunday.

Heard Mr Peter Whitney, in the Morning from Romans 11.33.— “How unsearchable are his judgments! and his ways past finding out.” This is part of the verse, the whole of which is the text of Saurin’s admirable Sermon upon the depths of the divine Judgments—but Mr Whitney most probably never read it— His afternoon Sermon was from Hebrews 12.1. [“]Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of Witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us.”— Louisa C. Smith and my namesake nephew dined with us— I read the 7th. Sermon of Saurin, upon the punishment of the unpardonable Sin— This and the preceding discourse, are by far the best dissertations upon that difficult subject that I ever saw or heard— Saurin here lays down the doctrine of Association of ideas, as in a preceding discourse he uses against transubstantiation the whole argument of Hume against Miracles— Evening visit with Charles at Coll. Quincy’s— The ladies also went— Mr Beale and Edward Miller were there.
3. IV. Monday

Charles went into Boston, and returned to dine— Mrs Adams went also to Boston, and took with her my Son John’s Child Mary Louisa, to have leaches applied to her temples, for the inflammation in her eyes, with which she is still afflicted. They came back at 4. in the afternoon— Doctor Charles Gordon, one of the young Physicians who has come to take the place of Dr Phipps, brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Joseph Richardson at Hingham. At 6 in the afternoon I bathed with Charles, at the wharf, and swam five minutes, probably the last time for this Season— I continue writing to W. L. Stone upon Anti-Masonry, and resumed the Biography of my father and the perusal of his Journals.— Find myself again arrested in my progress, by indecision— Continued this afternoon to write upon the draught of a Will—difficulties there— Walk to Mrs T. B. Adams’s and gave her a Letter from her Son Isaac Hull at West-Point— She was in her Chamber, unwell— Rhumatic numbness— Received from Governor T. L. Winthrop a Phial of Eye-water.
4. V. Tuesday.— Squantum.

Rainy and Stormy day— At Noon I rode with Charles to Squantum, and attended the annual Meeting of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge. The only proprietors present besides myself, were Thomas Greenleaf Clerk, George W. Beale, Treasurer, and Edward Miller— I presided at the Meeting— The Clerk and Treasurer were re-elected for the ensuing Year; and the Official Oaths were administered to them by me, as a Justice of Peace throughout the Commonwealth. The Directors of the last year were all rechosen, and the Meeting was adjourned. We had a Cod and Clam Chowders for dinner. Mr J. M. Gourgas, E. Price Greenleaf and my Son Charles being of the company— We came home about five in the afternoon, the weather still dull and gloomy— Our fruit was very indifferent— Peaches, Pears, Plums scarcely fit to be seen, and not better tasted— Wrote a short, digressive Letter to William L. Stone In the biography of my father I came to the year 1761. and to the Argument of James Otis, against the Writs of Assistance
5. IV.15. Wednesday

Deacon Adams was here, and proposed to sell me six Acres belonging to him and his brother, of fresh meadow interlocked with my Penn’s valley farm— He wished also to borrow money, and to deepen a ditch between their Land and mine. I promised, if the weather is fair to call at his house to-morrow at 4 P.M— Mr Gourgas was here, and I told him how I intended to despose of my brothers farms at Braintree and at Medford Mortgaged to me— He will see the Judge of Probate—tomorrow— Mr and Mrs Gorham Brooks of Watertown paid morning visits. Dr and Mrs Waterhouse Came from Cambridge and dined with us. Louisa C. Smith also dined here— I planted Wood house Apple seeds Wild Cherries and Plum Stones in my Nursery and Garden— Evening at Coll. Quincy’s, with my wife and daughter in Law—Mrs Minot and her daughter—Miss Parker with her Pretendu, Edmund Quincy, Mrs Green, Abigail and Anna Quincy were there— Mrs Quincy and Abigail Quincy played, and sung— Charles was very unwell all day and could not go out.
6. IV.30. Thursday.

Morning occupied, in my garden and nursery—with my Letters to W. L. Stone upon Anti-Masonry, and with the biography of my father. George Veazie interrupted me for payment of a Bill. I consulted Minot’s and Hutchinson’s Histories, for the narrative relating to the question in 1761. upon Writs of Assistance— My observations upon my growing trees are of no use, for I turn them to no Account— But my perpetual failures explain to me the reason, why other people do not raise trees from the seed, nut or acorn— I planted this morning Wild Cherries Wood-House Apple seeds, and Plum Stones— After dinner I walked over to Deacon Adams’s and with him, over my Penn’s valley farm— I agreed with him, that he should have the ditch dug between our Lands— I declined purchasing that which he offered me and authorised him to cut me some more Wood— I found only two or three White Oaks, bearing a few Acorns. a very few Ash seeds; but wild Cherries in great abundance— This is the only fruit that bears this year in great profusion, and is just now ripe. I was between three and four hours walking, and in my extreme weariness and stiffness of Limbs, received faithful admonition of the decline of my years.
7. IV. Friday.

My wife and daughter and Charles went to Boston this Morning, and returned to dine. Spent a Morning hour or two in my Nursery and Garden— Mark the difference between the D. G. Red Oaks and Black Oaks up from Acorns planted 7. And 8. Octr. 1831— After dinner I walked down to the Mount Wollaston farm. Saw Alpheus Spear, and took his parish-tax-bill— He did propose to consult a lawyer but reconsiders— My Orchard looks very unpromising— Some of the Trees are dead— Others dying— The last Winter killed fruit trees by the thousand— Of my seeds planted last fall a few have come up. Of the border forest trees there are great numbers alive, but strangling under the grasp of hard, treelike weeds— They will perish, by weeds, Sunshine, and frost. All the trees the Stocks of which were suckers have thrown out groves of Shoots from the roots, and die from the top— I walked home by the road— Mr Beale and Ann, Elizabeth C. Adams spent the Evening here; Gourgas came for her— He took my Oath upon a certificate of the cost of Mt Washington Bridge shares, to be sent to Washington.
8. V. Saturday.

Mr Burn brought me a new History of the Town of Plymouth, by Dr James Thacher, of which I took two copies. Mr Soper brought me a copy of an Affidavit made by him and published in the Boston Centinel of 11. March 1812, of his capture in 1810 and 1811. by Danish and French Privateers— He says he has applied to Mr John Parker to know if he has put in claims before the Danish and French Commissions, but received no answer. I took his paper, and promised to do for him what I could— In the Nursery I planted Wood house Apple-seeds and wild Cherries between the seedling Peach-trees of this year on the two seeds of the central alley, and trimmed an English Oak— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Another case of malignant Cholera in Boston yesterday— In Washington it is raging with great mortality. I wrote—on Masonry, to W. L. Stone— On the biography of my father and on the draught of my Will. Towards Evening I walked on the road to Neponset Bridge, from the 7th. to the 6th. Mile-Stone, and back, each in 17. minutes— These Milestones have been set up since the last Autumn.
9. V. Sunday

Heard Mr Lamson of Dedham, in the Morning from 3. Philippians—13—[“]But this one thing I do, forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth unto those things which are before, 14. I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.” and in the afternoon from Jeremiah 13.16. [“]Give glory to the Lord your God, before he cause darkness, and before your feet stumble upon the dark mountains, and while ye look for the light, he turn it into the shadow of death, and make it gross darkness”— The morning discourse on the progressive pursuit of virtue was excellent—that of the afternoon upon delays in preparation for death was very good— Mr. Lamson is a very good preacher— He dined with us— I read the 8th Sermon in the first Volume of Saurin—upon Alms— He treats the Subject in a manner somewhat singular, and altogether argumentative without any attempt at the pathetic— I finished the fourth Letter to W. L. Stone, on the entered Apprentice’s Oath— Johns child Louisa, is confined to a dark chamber with inflamed eyes.
10. V. Monday

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. John’s child is again very ill with the inflammation in the eyes, and must be kept in a dark room. Dr Woodward was sent for and ordered a blister on the back of the neck— Changed my Bed chamber— Mr Lord was here, with his Son a boy of 7. years old— Mr Pierpont has read and approves Dermott and Lord will publish an Edition of 1000 copies and give 100 dollars for the copy-right.— He will shew the Manuscript again to Mr Pierpont; mention the author and ask further critical remarks— Mr Nathaniel Curtis was here to confer with me concerning the further Execution of W. N. Boylston’s Will—paid 357. 1/3 the allowance by the Judge of Probate— We agreed that it would be most advisable to sell as occasions may offer the Real Estate in Boston. He left with me the Letter Book and I am to prepare the draught of a Letter to Petty Vaughan. After dinner I called upon Captain John Souther—Representative, Select Man and Assessor— He insists that the Assessors have the right to tax the owner in fee of Lands under Lease to the Parish tax. And that they have no right to tax the Lessee—but he engaged to take the opinion of Judge Jackson, on the point of Law.
11. V. Tuesday.

Charles went to Boston this Morning, with his Mother— They returned to dine— I visited the Nursery and planted Wild Cherries, Wood-house Apple seeds and Althea seeds along the borders of the Alley in the Nursery— After dinner we had visits from General and Mrs Sumner, with her Son, Mr Perry, from Mr and Mrs Tarbell, and from Mr J. S. Wright, with whom there were three other Gentlemen who did not alight. One a Partner of Mr Backus who was killed at the Railway the 26th. of July. Charles transplanted four rows of Strawberries in the Garden. The Cholera is raging dreadfully at Washington—and since yesterday Morning there have been six fatal cases of Cholera at Boston— May the Providence of God be felt in Mercy— I spent almost the whole day in genealogical enquiries to answer a Letter from Elisha Thayer. This plunges me into Winthrop’s Journal— The Wonder-working Providence and other interminable investigations.
12. IV. Wednesday.

Rainy Night and Morning—cleared up Cold. Finished the Letter to Elisha Thayer— Received Letters from Nathaniel Curtis and John A. Smith which ought to be immediately answered. I cannot help wasting my time— Mr and Mrs Edward Everett, and Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks came and dined with us— Mr and Mrs Brooks remained at New-York during the greatest severity of the Cholera, and came from thence only a few days since— John’s Child Louisa, had horse-radish leaves applied to the place where the blister had been on the back of her neck; but the operation was too severe— They were obliged to take them off. We had the remainder of the Strawberry patch covered this Morning in Rows, and I planted alternately Wood house Apple seeds and wild cherries on the sides of my Nursery Alley. Noah Curtis was here this Morning, and settled for Goose Pasture. He thanked me also for the Documents that I sent him last Winter.— I wrote to Charles Folsom, accepting an invitation to deliver the next anniversary Φ.Β.Κ. Oration, if my health should permit— The Cholera here and all over the Country— The illness of my grand-child, and the decaying condition of my affairs afflict me— [symbols]
13. IV. Thursday.

Charles and his wife went to Charlestown, and dined at Mr Edward Everett’s— They returned this Evening— Mr Jotham Lincoln came to make enquiries concerning a Petition which he had as Administrator, before Congress, at their last Session— There was a Bill in his favour which passed the House of Representatives; but what became of it in the Senate I do not know, or do not recollect— It did not pass— Mr Lincoln asked my attention to it at the next Session, which I promised, and hope not to forget— Henry Hardwick called to renew a proposal, which he has urged repeatedly to purchase a strip of Salt-Meadow adjoining to his Land on the Mount Wollaston farm— He wants about a Quarter of an Acre— I told him I would go down there the week after next, examine the spot, and would let him have the land if I could without injury to the farm— Louisa C. Smith dined with us. I walked out, and gathered a few White Beech, and Tupelo Seeds— The Red-Oak, bears this year a very few Acorns— Scarcely any other Oaks bear at all— We had fire in the parlour this Evening First time for the Season.
14. V:30. Friday.

A frosty morning, and a wasted day— Wasted upon trifles— Closed the Volume of a Letter Book, commenced on the 18th. of Feby. 1830. As I left the Book here in Decr. 1830. until my return from Washington the last of April 1831. This Volume contains my Correspondence for about two years, and it has furnished a large portion of my occupations during that time— An Oration— An Eulogy— Two Reports in Congress, a Speech on the apportionment, two other Speeches suppressed, Six Chapters in the American Annual Register of 1827. 8. 9. One chapter in the Register of 1830. A Letter to Speaker Andrew Stevenson, Dermot M’Morrogh—a Version of the Psalms, and a few small fugitive Poems, have constituted the remainder of my vigils during that period to say nothing of the Diary— The same labour devoted to the biography of my father would have completed it—and I have made no progress in it— I wrote to John A. Smith, to my Son John, and to R. Rush— Planted Wood house Apple Seeds, and wild Cherries in rows on the sides of the central alley to the middle of the Nursery. Pear seeds in White earthen Pot— Index to Letter Book.
15. V.30. Saturday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Jonathan Hill is a Revolutionary Soldier 83 years of age; a Pensioner of the act of 1818 at 8 dollars a Month— He lives at Abington, and walked yesterday to Boston to receive his half year’s pension. And returned as far as Milton last Evening— He came to ask me to procure for him his discharge from the army, signed by General Washington in 1783 after the close of the War— He sent it in 1818 to the War Office to procure his Pension, and now wishes to have it returned to him. He gave me an order to receive it, which he signed by making his mark— I asked him how it happened that he could not sign his name. He said he was born at Stoughton. That his father was very poor, and bound him out to a man who never gave him any Schooling— He believed he should have had an action against him, for if he had known how to write he would have been an Officer. He is bent nearly double, but said he never was sick, and never drank Spirits or Cyder. He talk’d all his battles o’er again, and seemed like a preserve in the Cordial of his own Vanity— We had a morning visit from Mr Henry Brooks and Miss Gorham— I resumed the Biography—answered a Letter from R. Walsh; commenced a Dedication and Preface to Dermot, and planted 3 whole Wood house Apples in the Nursery.
16. V:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Thomas B. Gannett of Cambridge-Port, in the forenoon, from Proverbs 4.23. and in the afternoon from Matthew. 19.13.14.—first. “Keep thy heart with all diligence, for out of it are the issues of Life”— P.M. Matthew 19.13. “Then were there brought unto him little children that he should put his hands on them and pray; and the disciples rebuked them. 14. But Jesus said, Suffer little children, and forbid them not, to come unto me; for of such is the kingdom of Heaven.” I invited Mr Gannett to dine with us, but he declined, saying that he was not very well.— He said Judge Cranch’s Son, who is attending at the Theological School at Cambridge and resides with him, was very ill, of a bilious fever— Mr. Degrand came out from Boston and dined with us— After the Evening Service he walked with me, and I bathed and swam a few minutes at D. Greenleaf’s wharf— Degrand had walked out; I sent him in the Chaise partly home. Read the 9th. Sermon of Saurin, and last of the first Volume On the sufficiency of Revelation—from Luke 16.27. These Sermons are about three times as long as those that are at present in fashion. Saurin deserves to be studied for his method, and for his reasoning— He seldom attempts the pathetic, and has no remarkable flights of Eloquence— I wrote a Dedication and Preface to Dermot
17. III.30. Monday

I was roused at three this Morning and did not return to bed. I began an answer to a Letter from Dr Waterhouse; and sending him an extract from the Astronomics of Manilius, upon the influence of Comets on Epidemics, attempted a translation of it in verse— Got about half through, and left the rest for to-morrow. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Deacon Spear was here and enquired, if I should sell standing wood this Autumn— I propose to clear off the remainder of Lawyer’s Common; and he will view the Pine Hill Lots to see if anything can be taken from them. The deacon was disposed to discuss Politics, but I refrained— Charles brought me out the first Volume of Leland’s History of Ireland.— I wrote a page of biography, and towards Evening a page in my draft of a Will. These ought with the Diary to be my first occupations every day.— And whenever I neglect them it is a day lost— From the perverseness of my nature it is precisely them that I do neglect— I visited garden and nursery after dinner— I fail almost universally with my Stakes; but make useful observations with those that do success— John’s Child Louisa, is still distressingly unwell—and was this Evening fractious—
18. V:15. Tuesday.

Finished the version of the extract from Manilius upon the influence of Comets upon Epidemics, and the Letter to Dr. Waterhouse—from whom I received yesterday another. Visited my garden and nursery where I planted whole Woodhouse Apples, and horse-plums, between four Stakes—for observation— Almost all my Stakes of former years are lost, so that my chain of observation fails— I find in the ground many of the acorns which I planted last Autumn and which never germinated. Henry Brooks and Miss Gorham came out and dined with us—and in the Evening I went with my wife, Charles and his wife to Boston, to the Soirée Musicale of the Hermann’s, five German Musicians from the Royal conservatory of Musick. It was in the Lecture Room of the Masonic Hall. They had only a Piano and a Violoncello, for accompaniment, and Sung short pieces of three four and five voices, without one female— They were pleasant and pretty, but the fashionable music has changed since I frequented Concerts and Operas— Rossini and Von Weber have taken the place of Paësiello, and Cimarosa— They performed this Evening one Piece of Haydn and one of Mozart— The rest were all of new Composers— The House was well filled— Of my acquaintance very few— Another generation. We came home, which we reached at 11. P.M.
19. V:30. Wednesday.

There seems to be a return of Summer— The Sun was so ardent that I did not venture upon my plantations in the Garden— I wrote to Eastburn for some copies of the Eulogy and to President Quincy to borrow Giraldus Cambrensis from the University Library— Mr Jesse B. Hawley of Jefferson, Ashtabula County Ohio, came to solicit a Subscription to build a Presbyterian Church there— As this is a flourishing part of the most flourishing State in the Union, and no accident of fire or other Calamity had befallen the Society, I declined subscribing and told him I thought they ought to bear the expences of their own public worship— Towards Evening I bathed and swam half way between Mr Greenleaf’s Wharves— Charles and his wife spent the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s I wrote a page of biography, a page and a half of the draught of a Will, and began a Letter to W. L. Stone.— Read three Letters of Madame de Sevigné—three Chapters of Thomas Morton’s new Canaan, and some pages of Dr Granville’s Travels—about Berlin.
20. IV.45. Thursday.

I wrote to W. L. Stone— A page of Biography, and finished the first draught of a Will, which I am now to revise and methodise— I visited my Garden and Nursery— Planted whole Apples and a Horse Plum, with ticketed Stakes, to recognize them again, if I come next Spring.— The red Oaks grow more rapidly than any others, having a Spring and a Midsummer growth; but scarcely any of them form a top bud— Nor do any of the Walnuts— I sowed two rows of seeds of the white Beech, and berries of the hornbeam; novelties of the present year— Staked and marked, one of the rows— Charles and his wife went in to Boston and dined at Mr Josiah Bradley’s— Came home in the Evening— Mr Gourgas brought me from Dedham a Letter from Elisha Thayer upon Genealogies; and I received from Mr Lord, the Manuscript of Dermot, with notice that he is ready to begin the printing. Mr Pierpont has read the manuscript again and made some further Remarks— I began also this day with Charles to compare my father’s old Journals with the copies of them that I have had made— There was a reported case of Malignant Cholera—a Workman at Josiah Bass’s.
21. IV. Friday.— Autumnal-Equinox

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— The day was showery and confined me to the house— Mr Whitney and his Son George made me a Morning visit— I wrote to Mr Lord, and sent him the Preface Dedication and Notice to be prefixed to Dermot— The Sickness of the man at Captain Bass’s yesterday was not the malignant Cholera— I wasted much of the morning in hunting up genealogies for Dr Elisha Thayer without success— Wrote a page of biography, and after dinner gave two hours to revisal of the draught of my Will— I ought not to live another Month without finishing it. In the Evening I revised for publication the first and second Cantos of Dermot— I received from A. B. Johnson, and read a Discourse upon Language, which might teach me a useful lesson, upon the fate which awaits almost all American Literary composition— I have reason enough to know it by experience— There is an amusing Letter to my father upon this American disposition, in Mr Johnson’s Discourse— Still I shall make my experiment.
22. IV. Saturday.

Dully and rainy day— The second that I have been confined almost entirely to the house— Walked only with Charles about a mile this Evening after dark— Compared with Charles the first little stitch’d Sheets of my father’s Journals in 1756. with the copy made by T. B. Adams junr in the Summer of 1829— Then made minutes in Chronological order of the subsequent Journals from 1758 to 1761. in the first and third Volumes of the copied Journal Fragments, which swallowed up all the Morning. This postponed till after dinner the finishing of the page of biography, and deferred the daily task upon the Will— I revised finally for the press, the second and third Canto’s of Dermot— Mr Pierpont’s remarks are almost exclusively confined to identical rhymes, and misplaced accents, of which he has detected a great number— I alter every passage to which he objects— Perhaps not always for the better— In the first composition, I took no pains to avoid identical rhymes, especially those which are the same only to the ear—such as martial and marshal—Scene, and seen— It is remarkable that French rhyme, generally more rigid in its rules than English does not exclude identical terminations— Dryden reproaches the French versification for this fault.
23. IV. Sunday

I revised this Morning the fourth Canto of Dermot, and altered every passage objected to by him and some others— It is now prepared for the press— Heard Dr Charles Lowell, from Genesis 16.13—[“]Thou, God, seest me”—a deeply impressive discourse, and in the afternoon from 1. John 3.2 “Beloved, now are we the sons of God; and it doth not yet appear what we shall be[”]— Dr Lowell dined with us, and his Son James Russell, a boy, eleven or twelve years old. I read the first Sermon of the Second Volume of Saurin Upon the assurance of Salvation, from Romans 8.37.38— Not so pleasing as some of those in the first Volume— His Discourses are all argumentative and hortatory— Somewhat objurgatory, without attempt at the pathetic I received from Cambridge, the Giraldus Cambrensis, in the original Latin, and also translated in the compilation of Hooker’s Chronicles— I have been tempted to add several Stanza’s, but will suppress the inclination, believing that what I have written is quite enough for an experiment upon public opinion. Mr Daniel Greenleaf was here this Evening.
24. V:15. Monday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I visited my Nursery. Planted a whole Office Apple and whole Plum, each between four Stakes— One of the Apple trees which I budded last Summer with Price Greenleaf, appeared to have failed, until after the first of August of this year—the bud then pushed out and unfolded three leaves— A Caterpillar half devoured them, and I took him off— The Shoot is now about five inches long, whether it will survive the next Winter is a question. The growth of all my Seedlings of this year is extremely stunted. I warmed myself by labour, and then returned to writing in the house. Two pages of biography, and after dinner a page of Schedule to be annexed to the Will— I had begun in the Morning, a Letter to Alexander B. Johnson of Utica, New-York— In the Biography I am at the Period, and read Hutchinson’s and Minot’s Histories— James Otis then first proposed the Congress of Committees at New-York. The Ladies took tea this afternoon at my brother’s Widows— Charles and I walked there in the Evening.—
25. V:15. Tuesday.

This Mr Van Arsdale introduced himself to me as a traveller from New-Jersey who had been introduced to me there some Years since. He did not introduce his companion to me by name— I had invited Dr Waterhouse and his Son in Law Professor Ware to dine with us this, or the first ensuing fair day, and Mr P. C. Brooks and Mr Frothingham, without qualification— The letter came; but the weather was half fair half foul; so that Dr Waterhouse and Mr Ware, did not come.— I planted Apple seeds in the Garden— Wrote part of the letter to A. B. Johnson, and compared a few pages of my father’s original diary with an imperfect copy made by W. C. Greenleaf—but my writing on the biography was abridged to a few lines, and my afternoon writing entirely suppressed— After a showery morning it cleared off so cold that I was compelled to resort to the parlour for a fire side— Mrs. Adams was quite unwell— The autumnal weather is decidedly setting in.
26. IV:15. Wednesday.

Deacon Spear came and informed me that he had fixed upon this day fortnight the tenth of October to make sale of my standing wood on Lawyer’s Common. He proposed also that sale should be made of wood on other Lands among which on that which was my brother’s at Braintree— He also proposed to me a subscription for deepening the Creek and rebuilding a Bridge at Houghs Neck and Rock-Island— I took the Subscription paper to carry down with me— Dr Waterhouse and Mr Ware, came from Cambridge and dined with us— I went with them before dinner to the Meeting House, to view the Monument to my father and mother. We found Mrs Miller, Mr T. Greenleaf’s two daughters, Caroline Whitney, and Elizabeth C. Adams laying down the Carpet— Mr Beale was also there. Dr Waterhouse is going to Worcester to the Electioneering National Convention. He appears to have been converted back from his Anti-Masonry— This day was nearly lost to me— I barely finished my Letter to A. B. Johnson; and visited my Garden and Nursery. Transplanted a few Strawberry Plants.
27. V. Thursday.

I have been about six weeks occupied in making a draft of a Will, with a Schedule of my property and debts, and incumbrances— The Month of September is closing, and in about six weeks more, I shall be required to go on to Washington— I have yet done nothing since my return, and must begin to act efficiently or do nothing— I therefore determine to make the preparation of my Will, my Morning’s work. Began upon it accordingly this Morning;—with the Resolution to complete and have it witnessed, on or before the 15th. of October. After breakfast I visited my Garden, and laboured about two hours Finished a row of Apple-Seeds in the Garden from tree to tree, opposite to the Nursery Gate— The rest of the time I was hoeing weeds— Despairing of success in planting, I now work with no rational motive but for exercise— I then wrote a page of biography— After dinner, I rode with the Ladies and Charles to Dorchester to General Sumner’s. but he was in Boston, and Mrs Sumner was unwell, so that we were not received. In the Evening I began a Letter to W. L. Stone.
28. III.45. Friday.

I was roused about an hour before the usual time of my rising—and in writing off my Will made a blunder which will cause an erasure; for I have not Patience to write it over again. After breakfast I planted in right Angles a row of whole Peaches and Pears in the Garden opposite to the Nursery Gate— Mr Lemuel Brackett came and proposed to me to purchase three Shares and Notes of the Quincy Canal Corporation; belonging to William Wood’s widow, and also his Brackett’s Wood lot upon Pine Hill—which I promised to take into Consideration. I wrote a page of Biography— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— General Dearborn was here this afternoon— He says he has been much indisposed since the close of the Session of Congress, but is now recovered— He looked at my Garden and Nursery and said he had lost a great number of Apple, Pear, Cherry, Plum and Peach Trees, killed by the severity of the last Winter’s frosts— Elizabeth C. Adams and Louisa C. Smith were here at tea, and Mr Gourgas in the Evening— I shewed to Mr Gourgas the Mortgages of my brothers farms at Braintree and at Medford, and told him I proposed to take possession of the latter to-morrow.
29. IV:45. Saturday.

We had received an invitation from Mr P. C. Brooks to dine with him this day at Medford, if it should not rain— The morning was lowering, but not absolutely foul till about the time when it became necessary to decide whether to go or stay— It then came on to rain, which continued all the remainder of the day— It confined me to the house, so that I was recalled even from my exercise of digging in the Garden— I continued drafting my Will till breakfast—wrote one page of biography and compared with Charles the copy of manuscript Journal, till dinner— Made out a Statement of account with John A. Smith after dinner, and wrote part of a Letter to William L. Stone in the Evening— A little, of many things—and not like John De Witt, one thing at a time— I received Letters from R. Rush, and R. Walsh— Read a few Letters of Madame de Sevigné, and heard Charles read some pages of Dr. Granville’s account of St. Petersburg.
30. V.45. Sunday.

Heard Mr Brooks, of Hingham, Morning and afternoon, from Acts 2.46. “And they, continuing daily, with one accord in the temple, and breaking bread from house to house, did eat their meat with gladness, and singleness of heart, 47. Praising God, and having favour with all the People.” The Subject was the operation of the Gospel upon the primitive converted Christians— I was well pleased with the Sermon; but Mr Brooks I know not why, is not a popular Preacher— He dined with us, and was pleasant as usual in conversation. I read the second Sermon of Saurin’s second Volume, upon the immensity of God— From Hosea—6.4. This preacher, loses himself and his hearers, in the depth of the difficulties which he starts and cannot solve. I continued the draft of my Will, and finished a letter to W. L. Stone— Sometime lost.

Day— Since my return from Washington— Rise between 4 and 6. Read 3 Chapters in the Bible and write till Breakfast at 8— Work in the Garden and Nursery two hours— Read and write miscellaneously till 2. Dine— An hour of idleness—then write till dusk and some times an hour before bed time at ten or eleven.
